short_description: This function trains a SVM model according to the training set iteratively.
long_description: This function is used to train a linear/non-linear SVM model for dense input data.  The training is an iterative process controlled by the paramters.  We may choose from linear kernel or non-linear kernels: polynomial, radial basis function (rbf) and sigmoid; we may also choose to project the attributes to a hash space or explictly record all the attributes as a list during the training.

input_tables.name: InputTable
input_tables.description: Name of the table containing the training samples. Each row consists of a sample_id, a set of attribute values, and a corresponding label.
input_tables.rDescription: Name of the table containing the training samples. Each row consists of a sample_id, a set of attribute values, and a corresponding label.

output_tables.name: ModelTable
output_tables.description: Name for the model table that the function will create.
output_tables.rDescription: Name for the model table that the function will create.

argument_clauses.name: SampleIdColumn
argument_clauses.rDescription: Name of the column in the data that contains the identifier of the training samples.
argument_clauses.description: Name of the column in the InputTable that contains the identifier of the training samples.

argument_clauses.name: AttributeColumns
argument_clauses.rDescription: Specifies all the attribute columns. Attribute columns must have a numeric value.
argument_clauses.description: Specifies all the attribute columns. Attribute columns must have a numeric value.

argument_clauses.name: LabelColumn
argument_clauses.rDescription: Column that identifies the class of the corresponding sample. Must be an integer or a string.
argument_clauses.description: Column that identifies the class of the corresponding sample. Must be an integer or a string.

argument_clauses.name: KernelFunction
argument_clauses.rDescription: Possible values are linear, polynomial, RBF, or sigmoid. The distribution exponential family used to compute the hash function. • For linear, a Pegasos algorithm is used to solve the linear SVM. • For polynomial, RBF, or sigmoid, a Hash-SVM algorithm is used. Each sample is represented by compact hash bits, over which an inner product is defined to serve as the surrogate of the original nonlinear kernels. The default value is linear.
argument_clauses.description: Possible values are linear, polynomial, RBF, or sigmoid. The distribution exponential family used to compute the hash function. • For linear, a Pegasos algorithm is used to solve the linear SVM. • For polynomial, RBF, or sigmoid, a Hash-SVM algorithm is used. Each sample is represented by compact hash bits, over which an inner product is defined to serve as the surrogate of the original nonlinear kernels. The default value is linear.

argument_clauses.name: Gamma
argument_clauses.rDescription: Only used when kernel.function is polynomial, RBF, or sigmoid. A positive double that specifies . The minimum value is 0.0. The default value is 1.0.
argument_clauses.description: Only used when KernelFunction is polynomial, RBF, or sigmoid. A positive double that specifies . The minimum value is 0.0. The default value is 1.0.

argument_clauses.name: Constant
argument_clauses.rDescription: Only used when kernel.function is polynomial or sigmoid. A double value that specifies c. If kernel.function is polynomial, the minimum value is 0.0. The default value is 1.0.
argument_clauses.description: Only used when KernelFunction is polynomial or sigmoid. A double value that specifies c. If KernelFunction is polynomial, the minimum value is 0.0. The default value is 1.0.

argument_clauses.name: degree
argument_clauses.rDescription: Only used when kernel.function is polynomial. A positive integer that specifies the degree (d) of the polynomial kernel. The input value must be greater than 0. The default value is 2.
argument_clauses.description: Only used when KernelFunction is polynomial. A positive integer that specifies the degree (d) of the polynomial kernel. The input value must be greater than 0. The default value is 2.

argument_clauses.name: SubspaceDimension
argument_clauses.rDescription: Only valid if kernel is polynomial, RBF, or sigmoid. A positive integer that specifies the random subspace dimension of the basis matrix V obtained by the Gram-Schmidt process. Since the Gram-Schmidt process cannot be parallelized, this dimension cannot be too large. Accuracy will increase with higher values of this number, but computation costs will also increase. The input value must be in the range [1, 2048]. The default value is 256.
argument_clauses.description: Only valid if kernel is polynomial, RBF, or sigmoid. A positive integer that specifies the random subspace dimension of the basis matrix V obtained by the Gram-Schmidt process. Since the Gram-Schmidt process cannot be parallelized, this dimension cannot be too large. Accuracy will increase with higher values of this number, but computation costs will also increase. The input value must be in the range [1, 2048]. The default value is 256.

argument_clauses.name: HashBits
argument_clauses.rDescription: Only valid if kernel is polynomial, RBF, or sigmoid. A positive integer specifying the number of compact hash bits used to represent a data point. Accuracy will increase with higher values of this number, but computation costs will also increase. The input value must be in the range [8, 8192]. The default value is 256.
argument_clauses.description: Only valid if kernel is polynomial, RBF, or sigmoid. A positive integer specifying the number of compact hash bits used to represent a data point. Accuracy will increase with higher values of this number, but computation costs will also increase. The input value must be in the range [8, 8192]. The default value is 256.

argument_clauses.name: Cost
argument_clauses.rDescription: The regularization parameter in the SVM soft-margin loss function : Must be greater than 0.0. The default value is 1.0.
argument_clauses.description: The regularization parameter in the SVM soft-margin loss function : Must be greater than 0.0. The default value is 1.0.

argument_clauses.name: Bias
argument_clauses.rDescription: A non-negative value. If the value is greater than zero, each sample (x) in the training set will be converted to ( x, b); that is, it will add another dimension containing the bias value b. This argument addresses situations where not all samples center at 0. The default value is 0.0.
argument_clauses.description: A non-negative value. If the value is greater than zero, each sample (x) in the training set will be converted to ( x, b); that is, it will add another dimension containing the bias value b. This argument addresses situations where not all samples center at 0. The default value is 0.0.

argument_clauses.name: ClassWeights
argument_clauses.rDescription: Specifies the weights for different classes. The format should be: “classlabel m:weight m, classlabel n:weight n”. If weight for a class is given, the cost parameter for this class will be weight * cost. A weight larger than 1 often increases the accuracy of the corresponding class; however, it may decrease global accuracy. Classes not assigned a weight in this argument will be assigned a weight of 1.0.
argument_clauses.description: Specifies the weights for different classes. The format should be: “classlabel m:weight m, classlabel n:weight n”. If weight for a class is given, the cost parameter for this class will be weight * cost. A weight larger than 1 often increases the accuracy of the corresponding class; however, it may decrease global accuracy. Classes not assigned a weight in this argument will be assigned a weight of 1.0.

argument_clauses.name: MaxStep
argument_clauses.rDescription: A positive integer value that specifies the maximum number of iterations of the training process. One step means that each sample is seen once by the trainer. The input value must be in the range (0, 10000]. The default value is 100.
argument_clauses.description: A positive integer value that specifies the maximum number of iterations of the training process. One step means that each sample is seen once by the trainer. The input value must be in the range (0, 10000]. The default value is 100.

argument_clauses.name: Epsilon
argument_clauses.rDescription: Termination criterion. When the difference between the values of the loss function in two sequential iterations is less than this number, the function stops. Must be greater than 0.0. The default value is 0.01.
argument_clauses.description: Termination criterion. When the difference between the values of the loss function in two sequential iterations is less than this number, the function stops. Must be greater than 0.0. The default value is 0.01.

argument_clauses.name: Seed
argument_clauses.rDescription: A long integer value used to order the training set randomly and consistently. This value can be used to ensure that the same model will be generated if the function is run multiple times in a given database with the same arguments. The input value must be in the range [0, 9223372036854775807]. The default value is 0.
argument_clauses.description: A long integer value used to order the training set randomly and consistently. This value can be used to ensure that the same model will be generated if the function is run multiple times in a given database with the same arguments. The input value must be in the range [0, 9223372036854775807]. The default value is 0.
